     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Education Board
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1432 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1432">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <div class="elementor elementor-1432" data-elementor-id="1432" data-elementor-type="wp-page">
          <section class="elementor-section elementor-top-section elementor-element elementor-element-597d9dc elementor-section-boxed elementor-section-height-default elementor-section-height-default" data-element_type="section" data-id="597d9dc">
           <div class="elementor-container elementor-column-gap-default">
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-100 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-f6a6d37" data-element_type="column" data-id="f6a6d37">
             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap elementor-element-populated">
              <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-4c181e2 elementor-widget elementor-widget-text-editor" data-element_type="widget" data-id="4c181e2" data-widget_type="text-editor.default">
               <div class="elementor-widget-container">
                <p>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  Education Board
                 </span>
                 <span style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 47.2px;">
                  (EB)
                 </span>
                 <span style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 47.2px;">
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  consists of one representative of each
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt; color: #1a1a1d;">
                  Consortium
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  University and the Coordinator. Each representative is appointed by its respective Consortium University and will be appointed for one year.
                 </span>
                </p>
                <p>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  Education Board is responsible for the selection of master students and visiting scholars
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt; color: #18181c;">
                  according to the
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  selection criteria
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt; color: #18181c;">
                  created by the Consortium Committee. All members of the Education Board have to agree on
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt; color: #18181c;">
                  applicants so that there is a mutual understanding and agreement on the quality of
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt; color: #18181c;">
                  students acceptable to the programme.
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  Education Board
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt; color: #18181c;">
                  decides on the
                 </span>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  3
                 </span>
                 <sup style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  rd
                 </sup>
                 <span style="font-style: inherit; font-weight: inherit; text-align: justify; text-indent: 35.4pt;">
                  semester mobility path and internships of the students. Education Board holds regular e-meetings and convenes at least twice a year. Minutes of these meetings will be recorded and kept
                  <span style="font-family: Calibri, sans-serif;">
                   <span style="font-size: 14.6667px;">
                    .
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </span>
                </p>
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </section>
          <section class="elementor-section elementor-top-section elementor-element elementor-element-392c40f elementor-section-boxed elementor-section-height-default elementor-section-height-default" data-element_type="section" data-id="392c40f">
           <div class="elementor-container elementor-column-gap-default">
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-20 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-0a22516" data-element_type="column" data-id="0a22516">

             </div>
            </div>
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-20 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-2c6b8ff" data-element_type="column" data-id="2c6b8ff">
             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap">
             </div>
            </div>
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-20 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-6301f35" data-element_type="column" data-id="6301f35">
             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap">

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Strategic Advisory Board
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">

      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1437 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1437">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          <strong>
           Strategic Advisory Board
          </strong>
          (SAB) consists of representatives of Associated Partners, representatives of Consortium Universities and the SEAS 4.0 Coordinator. The Strategic Advisory Board is installed to advise the Consortium Committee on the set-up of the SEAS 4.0 Master Programme and the relevance for the professional practice.
         </p>
         <p>
          The Strategic Advisory Board normally meets once a year, but may be convened on the motion of one of the Consortium Committee. Minutes of these meetings will be recorded and kept.
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           AUGUSTEA TECHNOSERVICES Ltd,
          </strong>
          Giuseppe LONGOBARDI
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           BUREAU VERITAS MARINE & OFFSHORE
          </strong>
          , Sime MALENICA
         </p>
         <p>
          <b>
           CINECA,
          </b>
          Claudio ARLANDINI
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           CONFITARMA,
          </strong>
          Umberto D’AMATO
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           ICAT,
          </strong>
          Tomislav URODA
         </p>
         <p>
          <b>
           NAVANTIA –
          </b>
          José Luis GONZALES LEAL
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           MEMORIAL UNIVERSITY OF NEWFOUNDLAND,
          </strong>
          Lorenzo MORO
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           UNIVERSITY OF ANTWERP,
          </strong>
          Edwin VAN HASSEL
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>

					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Student Council
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1445 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1445">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          The Student Council consists of four representatives elected by students. The Student Council is installed to advise the Consortium Committee on the organisation of the SEAS 4.0 Master Programme. The Student Council has regular contacts with the SEAS 4.0 Coordinator.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Intake 2024/25
          </strong>
          Student Council election has been held on February 4th 2025.  For the Intake 2024/25 students representatives are:
         </p>
         <p>
          Anel
          <strong>
           BAYANGALIYEVA
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          Pedro Henrique
          <strong>
           DE MELO ESTRELLA
           <br/>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          Lemuel
          <strong>
           HORNSBY-ODOI
           <br/>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          Wassim
          <strong>
           KACI
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Intake 2023/24
          </strong>
          Student Council election has been held on October 26th 2023.  For the Intake 2023/24 students representatives are:
         </p>
         <p>
          Dmitrii
          <strong>
           APARIN
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Visiting Scholars
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1141 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1141">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          SEAS 4.0 Master programme welcomes interested scholars to join the program.
         </p>
         <p>
          Professors can join the Master for active participation to the: lectures, seminar, research, project, students follow up. SEAS 4.0 grant will finance at least 4 invited scholars/guest lecturers per intake, engaged in the master activities for at least 8 weeks in total.
         </p>
         <p>
          The invited scholars/guest lecturers will be selected in accordance with the consortium’s specific
          <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/scholarship/scholar-grants/">
           selection criteria
          </a>
          for scholars and bring concrete added value to the delivery of the SEAS 4.0.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           How to apply?
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           Complete the identification form
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/scholar-application-form/">
            online form here
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           Upload your CV
          </li>
          <li>
           Upload your lectures proposal –
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/SEAS-40_Template_Scholars-Lectures-Proposal_Intake_23_24.pdf">
            download template
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           After completing the form, your application will be evaluated
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          When your request is approved, an agreement will be drafted by the SEAS 4.0 coordination office and sent to you for signature.
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
         <div id="gtx-trans" style="position: absolute; left: 438px; top: 304px;">
          <div class="gtx-trans-icon">
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </article>
      </main>
     </div>

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Join the Consortium
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1139 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1139">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          <strong>
           Is your company interested in becoming an associate partner of the EMJMD SEAS 4.0 Consortium?
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           As an associate partner you have the opportunity to:
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           Jointly conduct Master Thesis
          </li>
          <li>
           Advise the SEAS 4.0 Strategic Advisory Board to adjust the education contents to the up-to-date industrial requirements
          </li>
          <li>
           Provide industry related lectures/ seminars
          </li>
          <li>
           Promote and disseminate the Master Programme
          </li>
          <li>
           Support special events like the Challenge Week, Welcome Week
          </li>
          <li>
           Share information on EMJMD SEAS 4.0 website regarding new job opportunities or projects
          </li>
          <li>
           Contribute in strengthening the cooperation with industry through fitting internship stages
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          Importantly student applicants receiving positive recommendation letters from associate partners will receive an increased weighing on their application form.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           To become an associate partner please contact the EMJMD SEAS 4.0 Coordinator, Prof. Ermina Begovic, begovic@unina.it
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
         <div id="gtx-trans" style="position: absolute; left: 462px; top: 432px;">
          <div class="gtx-trans-icon">
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </article>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1466 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1466">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          Future Naval Architects should have skills and knowledge necessary to face sustainable lifecycle design of future ships, to enable implementation of advanced simulation and optimization procedures, and to apply digital technologies in ship production and management. Furthermore, the engineers are increasingly being challenged by requirements for efficient design of innovative and unconventional vessels, new shipping routes (e.g. in Polar waters), and more stringent environmental regulations.
         </p>
         <p>
          Hence, the goal of the SEAS 4.0 Master Programme is to educate and form talented young engineers with state-of-the-art knowledge related to new trends and maritime industry. Particularly, SEAS 4.0 will allow the development of advanced knowledge in ship design in augmented reality, industry 4.0 implementation in ship building process, simulation and optimization of ship structure and furthermore arctic technology and autonomous ships.
         </p>
         <p>
          Courses are delivered by university professors as well as scientific and technical experts.
         </p>
         <div id="gtx-trans" style="position: absolute; left: 588px; top: 32px;">
          <div class="gtx-trans-icon">
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </article>

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Mobility Scheme
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1161 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1161">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <div class="elementor elementor-1161" data-elementor-id="1161" data-elementor-type="wp-page">
          <section class="elementor-section elementor-top-section elementor-element elementor-element-25c97337 elementor-section-boxed elementor-section-height-default elementor-section-height-default" data-element_type="section" data-id="25c97337">
           <div class="elementor-container elementor-column-gap-default">
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-100 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-57230aaf" data-element_type="column" data-id="57230aaf">
             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap elementor-element-populated">
              <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-3a66a426 elementor-widget elementor-widget-text-editor" data-element_type="widget" data-id="3a66a426" data-widget_type="text-editor.default">
               <div class="elementor-widget-container">
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </section>
          <section class="elementor-section elementor-top-section elementor-element elementor-element-28bf3c0 elementor-section-boxed elementor-section-height-default elementor-section-height-default" data-element_type="section" data-id="28bf3c0">
           <div class="elementor-container elementor-column-gap-default">
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-100 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-da8da75" data-element_type="column" data-id="da8da75">
             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap elementor-element-populated">
              <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-2126b5a elementor-widget elementor-widget-image" data-element_type="widget" data-id="2126b5a" data-widget_type="image.default">
               <div class="elementor-widget-container">
                <img alt="" decoding="async" loading="lazy" src="http://www.testcoinor.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/mobility_schema.jpg" title=""/>
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </section>
          <section class="elementor-section elementor-top-section elementor-element elementor-element-fb3596f elementor-section-boxed elementor-section-height-default elementor-section-height-default" data-element_type="section" data-id="fb3596f">
           <div class="elementor-container elementor-column-gap-default">
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-100 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-9b66463" data-element_type="column" data-id="9b66463">
             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap elementor-element-populated">
              <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-516ada6 elementor-widget elementor-widget-accordion" data-element_type="widget" data-id="516ada6" data-widget_type="accordion.default">
               <div class="elementor-widget-container">
                <div class="elementor-accordion">
                 <div class="elementor-accordion-item">
                  <div aria-controls="elementor-tab-content-8531" aria-expanded="false" class="elementor-tab-title" data-tab="1" id="elementor-tab-title-8531" role="button">
                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-opened">
                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    Read more about Mobility
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-8531" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="1" id="elementor-tab-content-8531" role="region">
                   <p>
                    The first semester begins with a Welcome Week in Napoli (UNINA), where all first year students will gather, and will be introduced to the new institution, city and culture, course contents and structure, objectives of the degree and available language courses, among other topics. Seminars and presentations will cover all these aspects, which will be integrated with social, cultural and sport activities extending for the whole week. Courses will take place between September and December, followed by an examination period. The end of the semester will be the time for the 1
                    <sup>
                     st
                    </sup>
                    SEAS 4.0 Challenge Week ( described in more detail later).
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Once finished, students will have two weeks for moving to A Coruña (UDC), which is enough time for a reasonable transfer between cities. The Welcome Week will take place in February, following a similar approach to the one described in the first semester. Instruction period will last from February to May, culminating in  the SEAS 4.0 Workshop Week (also described later in detail). Two exam periods are planned between June and July. The first corresponds to the first opportunity for the courses of the second semester. The second period corresponds to the second opportunity of the exams of the courses of both first and second semesters. In the case of the exams of the first semester (corresponding to courses developed in UNINA), exams will be sent from UNINA to UDC, and staff from UDC, with expertise in the topic of the course, will carry out the exams in Coruña. Finally, the second semester will finish with the 2
                    <sup>
                     nd
                    </sup>
                    SEAS 4.0 Challenge Week, which follows the same approach as the first one, to be held in UNINA in the first semester.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    At the end of the second semester, students will propose their path for the 3
                    <sup>
                     rd
                    </sup>
                    semester among available alternatives. The Education Board of the SEAS 4.0 master will decide the final mobility path on the basis of students’ preferences, their academic results, and fair distribution among the CUs.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    The beginning of the third semester is scheduled for the beginning of September with a Welcome Week, which will take place in all four host institutions. Again, enough time has been given to travel and settle in the host location between the second and third semesters. In this case, courses will last four weeks and will be followed by a first period of exams (first opportunity for third semester exams).
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    The period for the internship and the development of the Master Thesis will begin, lasting for more than three months. A second period for exams has been planned at the end of January and it corresponds to the second opportunity for third-semester exams. In this case, as students may be outside of the host institution, remote examinations in Associate Universities or Industrial Partners could be done, following a similar methodology as defined for the second semester. Once all exams have been passed and the Master Thesis developed, its defence will take place during the first week of February in Napoli (UNINA), which will be followed by the Master’s Graduation Ceremony, where students from all mobility tracks will again gather in the same location and time, and celebrate the completion of the program.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </section>
         </div>
        </div>
       </article>

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Courses
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1090 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1090">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          The Master programme SEAS 4.0 is designed as a Multidisciplinary master, embracing
          <strong>
           Sustainable Design
          </strong>
          with
          <strong>
           Industry 4.0 elements
          </strong>
          through the
          <strong>
           student centered education
          </strong>
          . By its definition “
          <strong>
           Student-centered instruction
          </strong>
          ” focuses on skills and practices that enable
          <strong>
           lifelong learning
          </strong>
          and
          <strong>
           independent problem-solving
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <p>
          On this respect, the program has been built around a series of content blocks which represent the basic topics which have to be developed during the SEAS 4.0 master degree in order to provide the full spectrum of knowledge needed to fulfil the SEAS 4.0 academic objectives. These content blocks are the following:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <em>
             Energy Efficiency and Sustainability (EES).
            </em>
           </strong>
           Block which includes the courses directly related to increasing the sustainability and efficiency of ships, from design stage to life cycle analysis.
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <em>
             Simulation and modelling (SIM).
            </em>
           </strong>
           One of the main needs of 4.0 industry is to obtain tools to simulate the processes that are under analysis, so that optimization and control strategies could be adopted to increase the efficiency of such processes. In the case of SEAS 4.0 proposal, simulation and modelling mainly covers structures, hydrodynamics and ship motions in the field of ship design and shipbuilding processes in the field of ship construction.
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <em>
             Information systems and data management (IDM).
            </em>
           </strong>
           This block groups all courses related with data collection and analysis and the development of information systems, basic while implementing 4.0 industry paradigm.
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <em>
             Robotics & Autonomous Systems (RAS).
            </em>
           </strong>
           Finally, this block includes courses which cover the field of marine robotics and autonomous vehicles, which are always associated not only to sustainability, but also to 4.0 industry concepts.
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <em>
             Polar routes challenges in structure and technology (PR).
            </em>
           </strong>
           This group of courses is focused on the technological needs which face ships and floating structures operating in polar areas, not only but specially focused on the structural demands of such systems.
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <em>
             Ship operation, management and infologistics (SO).
            </em>
           </strong>
           In this group of courses the aspects related to ship operation and management are included, considering safety, economical and operational aspects, including also the necessary regulatory framework.
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          The full list of courses, distributed within their associated content blocks, is included below.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           <em>
           </em>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           <em>
            ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND SUSTAINABILITY (EES)
           </em>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           ALTERNATIVE FUELS FOR SHIPPING
          </li>
          <li>
           MULTI-CRITERIA DESIGN AND OPTIMIZATION
          </li>
          <li>
           SHIP DESIGN
          </li>
          <li>
           SMART SHIP DESIGN
          </li>
          <li>
           VIRTUAL AND AUGMENTED REALITY FOR LIFE CYCLE DESIGN
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           <em>
            SIMULATION AND MODELLING (SIM)
           </em>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           COLLISION AND GROUNDING AS DESIGN CRITERIA FOR SHIP STRUCTURES
          </li>
          <li>
           FUNDAMENTALS OF SHIP VIBRATION
          </li>
          <li>
           INNOVATIVE CFD APPROACHES
          </li>
          <li>
           INTRODUCTION TO MARINE COMPUTATIONAL FLUID DYNAMICS (CFD)
          </li>
          <li>
           MANOEUVRABILITY AND SHALLOW WATER SHIP HYDRODYNAMICS
          </li>
          <li>
           NUMERICAL SIMULATION OF MARINE PROPULSION SYSTEMS
          </li>
          <li>
           SIMULATION AND OPTIMIZATION OF SHIPBUILDING PROCESSES
          </li>
          <li>
           SHIP SEAKEEPING
          </li>
          <li>
           SHIP STRUCTURAL DESIGN
          </li>
          <li>
           STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS OF SHIPS AND OFFSHORE STRUCTURES
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           <em>
            INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND DATA MANAGEMENT (IDM)
           </em>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           DIGITAL TWIN IN MARINE SYSTEMS
          </li>
          <li>
           INDUSTRIAL INTERNET OF THINGS (IIoT)
          </li>
          <li>
           INDUSTRY 4.0 ENABLING TECHNOLOGIES
          </li>
          <li>
           STATISTICAL MODELS FOR MARINE TECHNOLOGY INNOVATION
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           <em>
            ROBOTICS & AUTONOMOUS SYSTEMS (RAS)
           </em>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           AUTONOMOUS MARINE VEHICLES
          </li>
          <li>
           ROBOTICS & UNDERWATER ROBOTICS
          </li>
          <li>
           VIRTUAL PROTOTYPING
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           <em>
            POLAR ROUTES CHALLENGES IN STRUCTURE AND TECHNOLOGY (PR).
           </em>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           ARCTIC TECHNOLOGY
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           <em>
           </em>
          </strong>
          <strong>
           <em>
            SHIP OPERATION, MANAGEMENT AND INFOLOGISTICS (SO).
           </em>
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           2
           <sup>
            nd
           </sup>
           GENERATION OF INTACT STABILITY CRITERIA
          </li>
          <li>
           INTELLIGENT DECISION SUPPORT SYSTEMS
          </li>
          <li>
           REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR MARITIME INDUSTRY 4.0
          </li>
          <li>
           SHIP DAMAGE STABILITY
          </li>
          <li>
           SHIP MANAGEMENT AND INFOLOGISTICS
          </li>
          <li>
           TRANSPORT ECONOMICS
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </article>
      </main>

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

     </h1>
    </div>

   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1452 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1452">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <div class="elementor elementor-1452" data-elementor-id="1452" data-elementor-type="wp-page">
          <section class="elementor-section elementor-top-section elementor-element elementor-element-51f69e8 elementor-section-boxed elementor-section-height-default elementor-section-height-default" data-element_type="section" data-id="51f69e8">

             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap elementor-element-populated">
              <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-5776672 elementor-position-left elementor-view-default elementor-mobile-position-top elementor-vertical-align-top elementor-widget elementor-widget-icon-box" data-element_type="widget" data-id="5776672" data-widget_type="icon-box.default">
               <div class="elementor-widget-container">
                <div class="elementor-icon-box-wrapper">
                 <div class="elementor-icon-box-icon">
                  <a class="elementor-icon elementor-animation-" href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Courses_Syllabi_Intake_24_25.pdf" tabindex="-1">
                   <i aria-hidden="true" class="far fa-file-pdf">
                   </i>
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="elementor-icon-box-content">
                  <h3 class="elementor-icon-box-title">
                   <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Courses_Syllabi_Intake_24_25.pdf">
                    Download syllabi in pdf format

                  </h3>
                  <p class="elementor-icon-box-description">
                   last update 07/11/2023
                  </p>

            </div>
           </div>
          </section>
          <section class="elementor-section elementor-top-section elementor-element elementor-element-7e01f26 elementor-section-boxed elementor-section-height-default elementor-section-height-default" data-element_type="section" data-id="7e01f26">
           <div class="elementor-container elementor-column-gap-default">
            <div class="elementor-column elementor-col-100 elementor-top-column elementor-element elementor-element-760256a" data-element_type="column" data-id="760256a">
             <div class="elementor-widget-wrap elementor-element-populated">
              <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-2c7be84 elementor-widget elementor-widget-accordion" data-element_type="widget" data-id="2c7be84" data-widget_type="accordion.default">
               <div class="elementor-widget-container">
                <div class="elementor-accordion">
                 <div class="elementor-accordion-item">
                  <div aria-controls="elementor-tab-content-4661" aria-expanded="false" class="elementor-tab-title" data-tab="1" id="elementor-tab-title-4661" role="button">
                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-opened">
                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    2nd GENERATION OF INTACT STABILITY CRITERIA
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4661" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="1" id="elementor-tab-content-4661" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         2
                         <sup>
                          ND
                         </sup>
                         GENERATION INTACT STABILITY CRITERIA
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        The course presents physical and mathematical background of the stability failure modes: parametric roll, pure loss of stability; surf riding, dead ship condition and excessive accelerations, considered by IMO 2
                        <sup>
                         nd
                        </sup>
                        Generation Intact Stability Criteria.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        The principal objective of the course is to contribute to a more profound understanding of the physics and ship dynamics faced within 2
                        <sup>
                         nd
                        </sup>
                        Generation Intact Stability Criteria. After two case studies on the application of the 1
                        <sup>
                         st
                        </sup>
                        and 2
                        <sup>
                         nd
                        </sup>
                        level of the SGISC criteria for different ship types, students should be able to link together the knowledge needed to.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        Ability to perform stability failure analysis.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Ability to find out the sound methodology for the direct assessment of stability failure modes
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Ability to use advanced techniques for ship dynamics modelling
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="elementor-accordion-item">
                  <div aria-controls="elementor-tab-content-4662" aria-expanded="false" class="elementor-tab-title" data-tab="2" id="elementor-tab-title-4662" role="button">
                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-opened">
                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    ALTERNATIVE FUELS FOR SHIPPING
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4662" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="2" id="elementor-tab-content-4662" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         ALTERNATIVE FUELS FOR SHIPPING
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        Nowadays ship marine plants are heavily dependent upon the combustion of fossil fuels and as such contribute to increased atmospheric concentrations of greenhouses gases and concomitant impact on the world’s climate.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The new air emissions regulations established by IMO and other measures adopted by MEPC to mitigate and reduce ship emissions have inevitably influenced the business strategy and policies of the shipping companies, operators and other related shipping industries.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The course offers a focus on the actual abatement technologies and alternative fuels able to satisfy both regulation requirements and business; secondly, hybrid power solutions and their impact on ship design  will be examined in order to give a complete scenario of the design solutions adoptable in the next future.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        The main objective of the course is to examine first IMO regulation description and the available compliances methods (Low sulphur fuels, scrubbers, LNG propulsion); secondly, to explore new solutions (fuel cells, bio-fuel) for future applications, by means case studies, considering some ship type.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="236">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="406">
                       <p>
                        Students are able to identify main fuel types and their characteristics
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Students are able to relate engine and fuel and their impact on environment and ship design
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Students are able to evaluate future solutions and their implications
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>
                   <div id="gtx-trans" style="position: absolute; left: -38px; top: -10px;">
                    <div class="gtx-trans-icon">
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="elementor-accordion-item">
                  <div aria-controls="elementor-tab-content-4663" aria-expanded="false" class="elementor-tab-title" data-tab="3" id="elementor-tab-title-4663" role="button">
                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-opened">
                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    ARCTIC TECHNOLOGY
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4663" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="3" id="elementor-tab-content-4663" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         ARCTIC TECHNOLOGY
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The course will provide an introduction into ice engineering. Different kinds of ice and their different failure modes including numerical methods for ice load simulations are presented. Main design issues including design philosophies for structures and systems for ice covered waters are introduced. The course shall enable the attendees to understand the fundamental challenges due to ice covered waters and help them to understand ice engineering reports and presentations. The structural design under ice loads will be carried out for an individual case.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The challenges and requirements due to ice can be explained. Ice loads can be explained and ice strengthening can be understood.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Professional Competence
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The challenges and requirements due to ice can be assessed and the accuracy of these assessment can be evaluated. Calculation models to assess ice loads can be used and a structure can be designed accordingly.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Personal Competence
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Social Competence: Students are capable to present their structural design and discuss their decisions constructively in a group.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Autonomy: Independent and individual assignment tasks can be carried out and presented whereby the capabilities to both, present and defend, the skills and findings will be achieved
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>
                   <div id="gtx-trans" style="position: absolute; left: -26px; top: -10px;">
                    <div class="gtx-trans-icon">
                    </div>

                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    AUTONOMOUS MARINE VEHICLES
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4664" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="4" id="elementor-tab-content-4664" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         AUTONOMOUS MARINE VEHICLES
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The contents of this course includes concepts relevant to the software and hardware systems needed to develop autonomous vehicles, including motions, autonomous perception, location, mission planning and guidance, and an introduction to their practical application to the marine environment.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The main objective of the course is to provide the students with an updated vision of autonomous robotics, and especially about intelligent control systems. In adittion, it will also provide a technical and regulatory approach to the field of robotics within an industrial framework, in particular autonomous marine robotics. In order to obtain these goals, and appart from the theoretical basis, students will work with real marine vehicles, thus developing the skills needed to tacke the implementation of real autonomous marine robots.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Capacity for applying mathematical and ICT methods and tools to define, design, operate and maintain advanced marine robotic systems and for understanding and developing the needed algorithms and methods.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>

                  <div aria-controls="elementor-tab-content-4665" aria-expanded="false" class="elementor-tab-title" data-tab="5" id="elementor-tab-title-4665" role="button">

                     <i class="fas fa-minus">

                    </span>

                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    COLLISION AND GROUNDING AS DESIGN CRITERIA FOR SHIP STRUCTURES
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4665" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="5" id="elementor-tab-content-4665" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         COLLISION AND GROUNDING AS DESIGN CRITERIA FOR SHIP STRUCTURES
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Course deals with the problem of collision and grounding of the ships. These marine accidents are rare events, but often leading to serious consequences. As it is impossible to prevents these, and other similar accidents such as object drops, fires, explosive etc., it is worth studying them in the attempt to design crashworthy and safe structures. The course deals with the complexity of such non-linear problems. Background to the subject is given and then both internal mechanics and external dynamics of ships is studied during ship collision or grounding.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Through the introduction to nonlinear finite element method analysis, obtain the knowledge needed for understanding, calculation and the analysis of the problems related to collision and grounding of ships as well as other fundamentally non-linear problems.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Students can understand the physics of non-linear problems in structural and fluid-structure interaction analysis
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Students can generate structural models and define analysis parameters for controlling non-linearities, contact problems and other parameters of analysis
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Students can understand the problem of stability of the non-linear computations and are able to make correct interpretation of the analysis results
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4666" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="6" id="elementor-tab-content-4666" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         DIGITAL TWIN IN MARINE SYSTEMS
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Requirements and components of a digital twin. Simulation software for physical systems. Basic concepts of sensoring, data process and communications. Model fitting algorithms. Basic introduction to IoT and Digital Twin integration platforms. Practical development of a simplified Digital Twin.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The objective of this course is to provide the students with knowledge in the field of digital twins, including the requirements, architecture and necessary components to develop one of these systems in the framework of the maritime sector.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The contents of this course include the analysis of the typical architectures of digital twins and the methodologies for the development and integration of numerical models, sensoring and communication devices, model fitting tools and learning techniques and the available implementation platforms.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Knowledge regarding basic concepts, structure and design of digital twins within the maritime sector.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Capability to practically develop a basic approach to a digital twin for a marine application.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>

                    FUNDAMENTALS OF SHIP VIBRATION
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4667" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="7" id="elementor-tab-content-4667" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         FUNDAMENTALS OF SHIP VIBRATION
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Oscillation of singe-degree of freedom systems,  vibration of beam and plates, analytical and numerical methods, finite element method, vibration excitation forces on ships, added mass in vibration analysis,  ship structural responses,  vibration criteria, vibration measurements.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Presentation of the basic notions of the vibration theory and ship vibration. Definition of vibration problems and consideration of possibilities for their solutions. Reliable prediction of vibration level in the ship design stage. Review of vibration measurement procedures and vibration remedy.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Integrate advanced mathematics (particularly differential equations), Mechanics I, II, and Strength of materials in the analysis of vibrations of mechanical systems; Calculate natural frequency of discrete and continuous vibration systems; Calculate the amplitude of forced vibration of discrete and continuous vibration systems; Estimate the specific effects of stiffness, inertia and damping Solve dynamic problems; Integrate mathematics in the calculations of vibrational behavior of simple models of mechanical systems and comment their vibrational behavior; Calculate the basic geometrical and inertial characteristics required for the calculation of global vibrations of ship hull.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    INDUSTRY 4.0 ENABLING TECHNOLOGIES
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4668" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="8" id="elementor-tab-content-4668" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         INDUSTRY 4.0 ENABLING TECHNOLOGIES
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The Industry 4.0 paradigm has derived into the proliferation of devices connected to networks and physical processes. Such devices make use of multiple essential technologies that enable integrating them into industrial systems able to control, monitor and manage the different involved processes.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        This subject reviews the latest and most popular Industry 4.0 enabling technologies, including sensing/actuation networks, augmented/mixed reality, blockchain, unmanned vehicles (e.g., AGVs/UAVs), additive manufacturing, cloud/edge/fog computing systems and cyber-physical systems. Moreover, the subject emphasizes the different aspects involved in the cybersecurity of the studied Industry 4.0 technologies: their potential cyber-attacks and possible mitigation measures. Furthermore, the most relevant industrial information management systems will be analyzed and studied, like ERP (Enterprise-Resource Planning), PLM (Product-Lifecycle Management) and MES (Manufacturing-Excecution System) software.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The main objective of this course is to provide the students with the essential concepts behind the latest and most popular Industry 4.0 enabling technologies, together with knowledge regarding the threats which could affect industrial connected systems.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        To understand and acquire knowledge regarding many of the most important Industry 4.0 enabling technologies.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        To be able to understand the key concepts related to the most popular Industry 4.0 information management systems.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        To be able to understand the implications at a security level of the diverse Industry 4.0 technologies and the basics of potential cyberthreats and the essential protection techniques.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-4669" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="9" id="elementor-tab-content-4669" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>

                         INDUSTRIAL INTERNET OF THING
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Introduction to IoT and IIoT. Applied architectures and devices (sensors and endpoints, actuators, power sources and hardware platforms). Types of networks (WAN, WLAN, WPAN), gateways and communication protocols. Data process (edge/fog computing, cloud computing, data analytics and machine learning, software platforms). User interfaces. Security.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        This course is focused on providing the students with practical knowledge in the Internet of Things (IoT) and, specifically, regarding its application to industrial environments (Industrial Internet of Things, IIoT). The theoretical lessons will cover a broad view of all relevant aspects of IoT, while practical lessons will prepare the students for carrying out the implementation of those theoretical concept
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The students will be able to understand and implement the basic theoretical concept of Internet of Things in industrial environments.
                       </p>

                      <td width="121">

                       </p>

                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Computational Optimisation, Parallel Computing, CFD-Procedures for GPU Architectures, Alternative Approximations (Lattice-Boltzmann & Particle Methods), Fluid/Structure-Interaction, Modelling of Hybrid Continua, Multi-phase flow approaches.
                       </p>
                      </td>

                       <p>
                        Objectives

                       <p>
                        Theoretical background of different CFD strategies and their use is simulations

                       <p>

                       </p>

                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Professional Competence
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Student can explain the theoretical background of different CFD strategies (e.g. Lattice-Boltzmann, Smoothed Particle-Hydrodynamics, Finite-Volume methods) and describe the fundamentals of simulation-based optimisation
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Knowledge
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Student should be able to structure and perform a simulation-based project independently
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Student should practice her/his team-working abilities, learn to lead team sessions and present solutions to experts
