                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-opened">
                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    INTELLIGENT DECISION SUPPORT SYSTEMS
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46611" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="11" id="elementor-tab-content-46611" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         INTELLIGENT  DECISION SUPPORT SYSTEMS
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Random processes: mathematical representation and tools for analysis of stochastic processes (time and frequency domains); ocean waves. Modelling of dynamical systems: state space and input-output models for linear systems; response amplitude operators. Seakeeping: methods for computation and assessment of ship responses in waves; motions, loads and fuel consumption. Signal processing: methods and tools for processing of noisy signals in the time and frequency domain. Estimation theory: parametric methods for estimation of signals; Kalman filtering and particle filtering; sea state estimation. Detection theory: statistical learning; detection methods for Gaussian and non-Gaussian processes. Decision support systems: design of decision support systems; human factors; study cases on safe marine operations and fuel efficiency.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The overall aim of the course is to provide an understanding of the engineering and mathematical analyses that form the basics of monitoring and decision support systems used for onboard/navigational guidance of ships. These techniques are used by naval architects and engineers in the technical departments of ship owners, in classification societies and ship consultancies. Moreover, the student will be trained in advanced methods to evaluate ship operations with regards to the increased focus on energy consumption and emissions from ship
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Understanding of monitoring and decision support systems used for onboard/navigational guidance of ships and capability to evaluate and optimize ship operations with regards to energy consumption and emissions and safety.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>

                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>

                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">

                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46612" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="12" id="elementor-tab-content-46612" role="region">

                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         INTRODUCTION TO MARINE COMPUTATIONAL FLUID DYNAMICS
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Introduction to Marine CFD. Conservation laws in fluids. Finite Volumes for diffusion and convection diffusion problems. Pressure-velocity coupling. Finite Volumes for transient flows. Concepts of turbulence and boundary layer modeling. CFD simulation process. Introduction to programming/simulation in OpenFoam.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        This course is focused on providing the students with an introduction to the field of computational fluid dynamics, with an application to the marine field. The course will cover from the basic principles of conservation and their characteristic equations, its discretization methods, to the finite-volume method and the basics of the CFD codes used for their solution, with a focus in the open source code OpenFoam.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Capacity to understand the basic concepts of computational fluid dynamics and to describe physical problems in this field with adequate mathematical models.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Capacity to set up test related with the fluid dynamics in the marine field and to solve problems related with numerical and physical errors.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Capacity to program a CFD tool based on C++ language.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>

                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    MANOEUVRABILITY AND SHALLOW WATER SHIP HYDRODYNAMICS
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46613" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="13" id="elementor-tab-content-46613" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         MANOEUVRABILITY OF SHIPS
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The main contents of this course include concepts regarding coordinates & degrees of freedom, the nonlinear governing equations of motion hydrodynamic forces & moments, rudder forces and rudder design, yaw stability, manoeuvring tests (constraint & unconstraint model tests), slender body approximation, the application of CFD simulations and the influence of shallow water, waves and wind.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The main objective of this course is to introduce the students to the basic concepts for the assessment and prognosis of ship maneuverability and to the development of methods for the analysis of maneuvering behavior of ships, including also the basics of characteristics of flows around ships regarding ship propulsion and manoeuvrability.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Students will acquire the ability to develop methods for analysis of manoeuvring behaviour of ships and explaining the Nomoto equation. The students will know the common model tests as well as their assets and drawbacks. Students will be able to evaluate a rudder design and to design a rudder by themselves.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                    <div class="gtx-trans-icon">

                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-opened">
                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    MULTI-CRITERIA DESIGN AND OPTIMIZATION
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46614" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="14" id="elementor-tab-content-46614" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         MULTI-CRITERIA DESIGN AND OPTIMIZATION
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The course describes the Multi-Criteria for Ship Design and Optimization, analyzing each step, from the identification of design problem, through the formulation of design model, till the structure response calculation using FEM.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Calculation of reliability and adequacy of structure and performed and. Modeling of “decision making” process are made..
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Techniques for multicriterial optimization of structures are described. The course is integrated with practical examples and exercise
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Acquiring the knowledge and application of methods for optimization and multi-criteria decision making in engineering system (airplanes, ships …) design.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Apply optimization and multi-criteria design methods for solving design problems in a field of complex engineering systems design.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Evaluate applicability of a particular design support methods with respect to the type and characteristics of a design problem and design problem mathematical model.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Design complex engineering systems using advanced design support methods
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                    <div class="gtx-trans-icon">

                 <div class="elementor-accordion-item">
                  <div aria-controls="elementor-tab-content-46615" aria-expanded="false" class="elementor-tab-title" data-tab="15" id="elementor-tab-title-46615" role="button">
                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">
                     <i class="fas fa-plus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-opened">
                     <i class="fas fa-minus">
                     </i>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    NUMERICAL SIMULATION OF MARINE PROPULSION SYSTEMS
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46615" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="15" id="elementor-tab-content-46615" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         NUMERICAL SIMULATION OF MARINE PROPULSION SYSTEMS
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Nowadays merchant ships, and especially naval vessels, are characterised by flexible and complex propulsion systems with powerful prime movers (e.g. gas turbines). The great power available to the propellers/waterjets entails a careful power management for a safe operation in every propulsive condition, including emergency ship manoeuvres. To this end, numerical simulation techniques can represent a very useful tool to design and optimise marine propulsion plants.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        In this regard, the course will deal with:
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Marine diesel engines and gas turbines performance;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Dynamic ship propulsion models;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Control logics in design and off design conditions;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Time Domain Simulation;
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Provide students with examples of the use of simulation techniques in marine industrial applications; Apply simulation to the ship propulsion design process; Assess ship energy efficiency and dynamic performance by simulation
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Ability to analyse numerical models, of different level, representing the dynamic performance of ship propulsion plants;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Ability to develop simple control logics for ship propulsion systems;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Ability to develop numerical simulation codes in Matlab-Simulink® environment
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                   <span aria-hidden="true" class="elementor-accordion-icon elementor-accordion-icon-left">
                    <span class="elementor-accordion-icon-closed">

                   <a class="elementor-accordion-title" tabindex="0">
                    REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR MARITIME 4.0
                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46616" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="16" id="elementor-tab-content-46616" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR MARITIME 4.0
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The course offers a comprehensive insight into the contemporary developments in the international maritime regulatory framework for safety and environmental protection. The course discusses the future of the maritime regulations in the era characterized by the fast-paced technology developments, globalization and climate change, resulting in demand for unconventional ships. Throughout the course a number of significant maritime accidents is used to exemplify the multifaceted nature of the regulations and (sometimes unexpected) implications for ship design.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The principal objective of the course is to contribute to a more profound understanding of the international maritime regulatory framework and to strengthen capacities of the future Maritime 4.0 engineers for the critical analysis and successful implementation of the regulations in design and operation of ships.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Students are able to understand the contemporary and future development in the international maritime regulatory framework and to approach in a critical way to implementation of the regulations.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                    <div class="gtx-trans-icon">

                     <i class="fas fa-minus">

                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46617" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="17" id="elementor-tab-content-46617" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         ROBOTICS
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The course will start with an introduction about robotics, giving a highlight to the current economy and market, especially related to the field of interest.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The basic concepts of robotic systems and kinematic structures will be presented, along with the direct and inverse kinematics problems and the trajectory planning problem.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Dynamics and control of a robot manipulator will be treated.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The course will finally introduce the technical nomenclature and required specifications in field robotics applications of interest.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The sought goal of the course is to give the basic concepts and technical terminology. After completing this course, the candidate should understand the different robotic system configurations, the problems related to the robot control, the possible applications in the field of interest, and the technical specifications.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Students will be able to:
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        understand the basic concepts of robotic systems and kinematic structures;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        understand the problems related to the robot control;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        think possible application of robotic system in their field of interest.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46618" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="18" id="elementor-tab-content-46618" role="region">
                   <table>
                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         SHIP DAMAGE STABILITY
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Introduction to ship damage stability. Practical methods to determine ship equilibrium after damage. Deterministic damage stability regulations. Probabilistic damage stability regulations (basic concepts of probability and current stability criteria). Practical implementation of deterministic and probabilistic damage stability regulations.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The objective of this course is that the students acquire the capabilities needed for understanding the process of damage of a ship or floating structure, including the theoretical basis, the capability of solving practical cases and the knowledge and application basis of contemporary damage stability requirements.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        To acquire the knowledge of the theoretical basis and the practical capabilities to analyse the stability of a ship or floating structure following damage, including its equilibirum, the residual stability levels and the verification of the applicable regulatory requirements.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                     <i class="fas fa-minus">

                   </a>
                  </div>
                  <div aria-labelledby="elementor-tab-title-46619" class="elementor-tab-content elementor-clearfix" data-tab="19" id="elementor-tab-content-46619" role="region">

                    <tbody>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         SHIP DESIGN
                        </strong>
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Describe the sequential and concurrent approaches used in the development of ship design procedure. Involve the students into design procedure steps. Evaluation and ranking of existing ships. Overview on Ship types and general layouts. Influences of Regulatory frame on design development and on ship characteristics. Freeboard and GT Assessment. Evaluation of brake horsepower. Life Cycle Assessment. Design for dismission. Technical aspects of Ship Management and Infologistics. Future trends in Ship Design
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        To provide students with state of the art knowledge on ship design development and optimization.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        To enable students to perform main ship characteristic preliminary assessment and to evaluate Regulatory frame influences.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        To enable students to consider the influences of Lyfe Cycle Assessment and Ship management and Infologistics on Ship design
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Analysis and ranking of existing ships by Multi Attribute Decision Making and statistical approaches
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Students are able to identify ship types and their main design features
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Students are able to assess main ship characteristics and pertinent Regulatory frame on the basis of given mission profile
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Students are able to perform a preliminary Life Cycle Assessment and to identify key roles in Ship management
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>

                      <td width="521">

                        <sup>
                         nd

                       </p>

Ability to set up a problem and use of properly selected tools and methods. Ability to “define” the seakeeping criteria at the design stage. Ability to write a technical report throughout three project assignments during the course
                       </p>

                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Title
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        <strong>
                         SIMULATION AND OPTIMIZATION OF SHIPBUILDING PROCESSES
                        </strong>

                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Course Subjects
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Course introduction. Basics of shipbuilding:  introduction to basics of shipbuilding, processes, building strategy and shipyard arrangement. Discrete event simulation: applications, systems, models & simulation, types of simulations, discrete event systems and processes, terminology and architecture of a discrete event model. Flexim: introduction and programming in Flexim (discrete event simulation software). Practical cases: data analysis, time measurement, experiment realization and result analysis; practical case related with shipbuilding. Advanced simulation techniques: introduction to “Process Flow” technique. Optimization: linear programming, nonlinear programming, metaheuristics.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        This course is focused on providing the students with knowledge in the field of discrete event simulation, and its application for simulating and optimizing the processes involved in shipbuilding. In the course, lectures are divided among theoretical ones, where the main principles of discrete events simulation and optimization are included, with practical ones, where Flexim is used to solve realistic cases
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Acquire knowledge about ship building strategy and the usual techniques applied during ship construction.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Capability to understand and implement simulation and optimization strategies of ship building processes.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>

                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        Description of multivariate data and inference about mean vectors. Elements of unsupervised learning: principal component analysis and clustering methods. Elements of supervised learning: problems in multivariate linear regression models; linear model selection and regularization (ridge regression, the lasso); reduction methods (principal components regression, partial least squares). Overview of classification methods. Statistical process monitoring and control: control charts for variables and attributes; the Hotelling control chart; regression adjustment; interpretation of out-of-control signals. Case studies through software environment R.
                       </p>

                       <p>

                        The course is applicative with the aim to train students on statistical tools for monitoring of complex data from marine technology systems. Applications and case studies are addressed to train students to formulate and define strategies for quality control and monitoring in order to support decision making process in a big data framework.
                       </p>

                        Ability to perform analysis through R, an opensource package for statistics.
                       </p>

                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The course offers a comprehensive insight into the transport economical aspects of a maritime transport chain. This includes maritime (sub) markets, ports, hinterland transportation and emission reductions (legislation and current developments).
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Objectives
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The objective of this course is to provide the students the insights of how ships are used to earn money. In order to do so, the functioning of the maritime markets needs to be understood. Also, it is the aim to explain that ships are part of a larger logistics chain and that the interaction in the port and with the other transport modes is vital. Next to that, also the working principals of a port are explained even as hinterland transport. Finally, the current developments regarding emission reductions in the total transport chain are dealt with.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        At the end of the course students will be able to understand how maritime world is part of a more complex logistic system and how ships and ports are integrated within it.
                       </p>

                       <p>
                        The overarching objective of the course is to give a thorough introduction to different topics related to interactive design and simulation. After completing this course the candidate shall understand and have insight into:
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Geometrical modelling evolution;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Reverse engineering techniques;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Virtual and real prototyping;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality in design.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                     <tr>
                      <td width="121">
                       <p>
                        Skills
                       </p>
                      </td>
                      <td width="521">
                       <p>
                        The ability to understand a PDM-PLM environment;
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The ability to use photogrammetry or other techniques to capture point cloud of free form shape.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The ability to understand VR and AR technologies.
                       </p>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </tbody>
                   </table>

                    </div>

                </div>

					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );

					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {

  <script type="text/javascript">
   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Learning Outcomes / Skills
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1157 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1157">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/5.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="wp-image-2517 alignleft" decoding="async" height="291" src="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/5.jpg" width="388"/>
          </a>
          The learning outcomes of the SEAS 4.0 Master Programme are defined with respect to the emerging necessity to enlarge and improve the knowledge of the Naval Architecture with the elements of Ship management, Infologistics and Sustainability concepts in the frame of Industry 4.0 in an environment of extraordinary interest for Industrial Partners and future career prospects.
         </p>
         <p>
          The learning outcomes are defined on four levels:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           general learning outcomes;
          </li>
          <li>
           specific skills and
          </li>
          <li>
           general and transferable skills
          </li>
          <li>
           soft skills
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           General learning outcomes
          </strong>
          SEAS 4.0 graduates will be able to:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           demonstrate knowledge, understanding and competences in applying sustainability precepts in ship life cycle; using model and simulation tools related with ship structures, motions and fluid dynamics; applying information systems and data management tools during ship design, construction and operation; design and operation of robots and marine autonomous vehicles; dealing with challenges regarding maritime Polar routes; fulfilling safety, economic and sustainability requirements in ship operation and management.
          </li>
          <li>
           use knowledge, skills, ideas, theory, and modern engineering concepts to create new or significantly improved real engineering applications;
          </li>
          <li>
           think creatively and explore new ideas outside of current boundaries of the field;
          </li>
          <li>
           identify, formulate, solve engineering problems within realistic constraints; and
          </li>
          <li>
           appreciate the impact of sustainable development goals in maritime transport
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Specific skills
          </strong>
          : SEAS 4.0 graduates will be able to:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           critically analyse, synthesise, interpret and summarise complex scientific processes;
          </li>
          <li>
           recognise and use theories, paradigms, concepts and principles, to design and undertake primary R&D within the context of multidisciplinary Design Process.
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          In addition to these, those specific skills obtained in each course, are described in the corresponding syllabus.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           General and transferable skills
          </strong>
          : SEAS 4.0 graduates will be able to
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           develop design skills, extendable in automotive and aerospace industry;
          </li>
          <li>
           apply research skills in independent design, execution, and presentation of original research;
          </li>
          <li>
           apply knowledge to address familiar and unfamiliar problems.
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Soft skills
          </strong>
          : SEAS 4.0 graduates will be able to:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           display adequate intercultural competence by successfully navigating multicultural learning environments;
          </li>
          <li>
           express an attitude of intellectual inquisitiveness and open-mindedness,
          </li>
          <li>
           implement basic management principles suitable for a multicultural working environment;  communicate effectively with stakeholders and industrial partners
          </li>
          <li>
           integrate strategies for self-managed and life-long learning.
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </article>
      </main>
     </div>

					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Examinations and Award
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1167 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1167">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          Grading systems of each host institutions will apply (10 – 30 UNINA, 0-10 UDC, 1-5 UNIZG, 5-1 TUHH). However, ECTS grading should also be used in each host for the sake of administrative purposes and ease of recognition.
         </p>
         <p>
          To progress from Semester 1 (30 ECTS) to Semester 2 (30 ECTS) the student must achieve a minimum ECTS grade of E (i.e. a pass) in all modules.
         </p>
         <p>
          To progress from Semester 2 (30 ECTS) to Semester 3 (12 ECTS in courses + 18 ECTS in Master Thesis + Internship) the student must also achieve a minimum ECTS grade of E in all modules. Examinations passed and credits earned at one university will be fully recognised by the other partners.
         </p>
         <p>
          To be awarded the Master Degree, the student must have successfully passed all modules at grade A to E under the ECTS scheme.
         </p>
         <p>
          All learning activities could be evaluated twice (except in certain cases, duly specified in the course description, i.e. training session).
         </p>
         <p>
          If a student fails once, he/she can present the exam a second time. If he/she has moved to the following partner institution the assessment will be done remotely. If the student fails a second time to the same evaluation, he/she won’t be allowed to follow the SEAS 4.0 Programme.
         </p>
        </div>
       </article>
      </main>

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Internship and Master Thesis
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1470 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1470">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <h3>
          <strong>
           Learning outcomes of the Internship and Master Thesis
          </strong>
         </h3>
         <p>
          The goal of the
          <strong>
           internship
          </strong>
          and
          <strong>
           master thesis
          </strong>
          is to prepare the students for their future careers. The students will have to prove that they can carry out a project based on their theoretical and practical knowledge and skills. The project must include a preliminary study, some substantial development, and a final evaluation of the results. Internship and master thesis could be combined, but each of them needs their own report.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Internship contents:
          </strong>
          The internship is an individual project that must be accomplished in a company, research center or laboratories of the host University. The topic is generally proposed by a company and approved by Education Board members. Students must deliver the
          <strong>
           internship report,
          </strong>
          in which the context of the work, the company, the problem addressed, the methodology, the accomplished tasks, the obtained results, and a conclusion (contributions and perspectives) are described.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Thesis contents:
          </strong>
          The master thesis is an individual project. The thesis manuscript should describe the context of the work, the problem addressed, the proposed solution with some justification of the design choices, an evaluation, a conclusion and all relevant appendices.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Work placement(s):
          </strong>
          Internship in the duration of
          <strong>
           375 hours
          </strong>
          in a company, research center or in laboratory at the host university.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Mode of delivery:
          </strong>
          Proposals of internships and master thesis topics could be done by professors, industrial partners or by students (strongly encouraged), and should include a brief description of the topic and tasks to be developed and indicate the academic advisor. Students should choose a topic as early as possible, but not later than the mid of the October of the 3
          <sup>
           rd
          </sup>
          semester.
         </p>
         <p>
          Education Board will review and approve internship positions and master thesis topics and communicate the final list to students. Internships can start as soon as the Education Board approves the “
          <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/SEAS-40_Template_Internship-Objectives-and-Project-Specificationles_Intake_21_22.pdf">
           <em>
            Internship Objectives and Project Specification
           </em>
          </a>
          ” document agreed with the company, research center or host University. It is possible to start the internship during the summer holidays. The student will keep the academic advisor informed of the progresses on a regular basis.
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
         <h3>
          <strong>
           Assessment methods and criteria
          </strong>
         </h3>
         <p>
          <strong>
           The evaluation of the internship
          </strong>
          : will be based on the report written by the student, and will be done by the Education Board on a Favorable/Non Favorable scheme.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           The evaluation of the thesis
          </strong>
          : includes the
          <em>
           written report
          </em>
          and an o
          <em>
           ral defense,
          </em>
          held at the
          <strong>
           University of Naples Federico II.
          </strong>
          It consists of an oral presentation,  question/answer session, and it’s followed by a short deliberation. The final grade considers the quality of the achieved work, the quality of the written report and the oral presentation, as well as the relevance of the provided answers.
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
         <p>
         </p>
        </div>
       </article>
      </main>
     </div>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Events and Activities
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1228 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1228">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          During the SEAS 4.0 master, there are different occasions where students will gather all together.
         </p>
         <p>
          While Welcome Weeks are more focused to introduce to the students a given host institution and location, the Challenge Weeks and Workshop Weeks are more academically-oriented, with an integratory view not only between the students but also with the industrial sector.
         </p>
         <h4>
          <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/Welcome_Week_Program_flyer_SEAS4.0_23_24_Sept_23.pdf">
           <strong>
            Welcome Week Intake 2023/24
           </strong>
          </a>
         </h4>
         <ul>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <a href="https://teams.microsoft.com/l/meetup-join/19%3aUf0cTQEH40SIzVY3iSZv-6GUcdR0kJEhlcofvcybCSY1%40thread.tacv2/1705161899468?context=%7b%22Tid%22%3a%222fcfe26a-bb62-46b0-b1e3-28f9da0c45fd%22%2c%22Oid%22%3a%2285d14600-ecf8-4a6a-baf1-ddfac409d72c%22%7d" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
             MEET US ON TEAMS
            </a>
           </strong>
           –  Q&A session for the applicants of SEAS 4.0 Intake 24/25 will be held on 30th January 2024 at 18:00 (CET time). Join us! –
           <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/SEAS_4_0_January_30th_2024_link_compressed.pdf">
            download brochure
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="https://youtu.be/AwKKHWVDlmU" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
            1st Intake Thesis Defense & Graduation Ceremony
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/Flyer_SEAS4.0_22_23_Larisa.pdf">
            Programme
           </a>
           – Visiting Scholar Prof. Larisa Buhin – Krenek
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/Welcome_Week_Program_flyer_SEAS4.0_20_23_Sept_22.pdf">
            INTAKE 2022/23 WELCOME WEEK PROGRAMME
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           EMJMD SEAS 4.0 –
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/SEAS_4_0_February_22nd_2022_link.pdf">
            MEET US ON TEAMS on February 22nd 2022 at 19:00
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/SEAS_40_Welcome_Week_Programme_2022.pdf">
            2nd SEMESTER WELCOME WEEK
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Welcome_week_SEAS40_21_Flyer.pdf">
            WELCOME WEEK
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/UNINA_Students_welcome.pdf">
            UNINA STUDENTS WELCOME SEAS 4.0
           </a>
           –
           <em>
            Friday 29th October
           </em>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/Workshop_Week_Program_flyer_SEAS4.0_2_5_Nov_21.pdf">
            WORKSHOPS
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/Sailing_Tomorrow.pdf">
            SEMINAR
           </a>
           <em>
            SAILING TOMORROW – Tuesday 23rd November
           </em>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Challenge2_Wartsila_merged.pdf">
            <b>
             WÄRTSILÄ CHALLENGE WEEK – 24  -28 January 2022
            </b>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            <a href="http://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Preliminary_program_2ndChallenge.jpeg">
             GHENOVA INGENIERIA – MAN Energy Solution  -NAVANTIA – CHALENGE WEEK 27

					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );

								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );

					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Application and Admission
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1093 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1093">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          In order to apply for the SEAS 4.0 Master programme you have to complete an online application form and upload a number of documents. It is important that you prepare your application according to the
          <strong>
           <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Guide-for-the-Online-EMJMD_SEAS40_Intake_24_25.docx">
            Application Guidelines
           </a>
          </strong>
          , as
          <strong>
           once submitted the application cannot be amended
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <p>
          SEAS 4.0 Education Board suggests to all Applicants to upload the link to downloadable personal video. (
          <strong>
           <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Tips_for_Creating_Your_Application_Video_Intake_24_25.pdf">
            Tips to prepare your video
           </a>
          </strong>
          )
         </p>
         <p>
          <!-- <strong>Useful links</strong>

<span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span>Erasmus Mundus Association

Erasmus Mundus Association LinkedIn page
<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/company/erasmus-mundus-students-and-alumni-association">https://www.linkedin.com/company/erasmus-mundus-students-and-alumni-association</a>

EMA list of Programme Representatives:
<a href="http://www.em-a.eu/en/about-ema/programme-representatives.html">http://www.em-a.eu/en/about-ema/programme-representatives.html</a><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_end"></span>

-->
         </p>
        </div>
       </article>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Application Procedure
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1477 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1477">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          Applicants are required to complete the online application procedure, providing documents and forms available through the EMJMD SEAS 4.0 website. The application procedure has following steps:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           Students must complete the
           <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/application-and-admission/on-line-application-form/">
            <strong>
             online application form
            </strong>
           </a>
           .
          </li>
          <li>
           The following documents are required and must be attached to the application form:
          </li>
         </ul>
         <ol>
          <li>
           Proof of place of residence (accepted documents are indicated in the
           <a href="http://www.consilium.europa.eu/prado/en/prado-start-page.html">
            PRADO website
           </a>
           )
          </li>
          <li>
           Copy of the ID/ passport (passport will be required for NON EU students)
          </li>
          <li>
           Certified copy of the transcript of records of all courses (in English)
          </li>
          <li>
           Certified copy of the highest degree obtained, stating credits, average grade and workload (in English)
          </li>
          <li>
           Copy of Language Certificate
          </li>
          <li>
           Full curriculum vitae in Europass format (
           <a href="https://europass.cedefop.europa.eu/documents/curriculum-vitae/templates-instructions">
            download template
           </a>
           )
          </li>
          <li>
           Letter of motivation to participate in the SEAS 4.0 Programme
          </li>
          <li>
           Recommendation letters from two referees (
           <strong>
            <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Reference_Letter_Content_Intake_24_25.pdf">
             download template
            </a>
           </strong>
           )
          </li>
          <li>
           Declaration of Honour  of
           <strong>
            <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Declaration_of_Honour_Programme_Applicants_Intake_24_25.pdf">
             Programme
            </a>
           </strong>
           /
           <strong>
            <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Declaration_of_Honour_Partner_Applicants_Intake_24_25.pdf">
             Partner Countries Applicant
            </a>
           </strong>
           (download template)
          </li>
          <li>
           A link to a downloadable personal video in which you should address your prior experiences and motivations. The video must not exceed five (5) minutes. You can
           <strong>
            <a href="https://www.master-seas40.unina.it/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/SEAS-40_Template_Tips_for_Creating_Your_Application_Video_Intake_24_25.pdf">
             download here
            </a>
           </strong>
           tips for creating your
           <strong>
            application video
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           Special needs evidence
          </li>
          <li>
           Any supplementary information that may be consider relevant by the Applicant
          </li>
         </ol>
         <p>
         </p>
        </div>
       </article>

					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

   <div class="page-header">
    <div class="container">
     <h1 class="entry-title">
      Admission Requirements
     </h1>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="site-content" id="content">
    <div class="container left-sidebar" id="content-inside">
     <div class="content-area" id="primary">
      <main class="site-main" id="main" role="main">
       <article class="post-1480 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-1480">
        <header class="entry-header">
        </header>
        <div class="entry-content">
         <p>
          SEAS 4.0 EDUCATION BOARD will be responsible for
          <strong>
           coordination of admissions.
          </strong>
          The Programme is open to
          <strong>
           APPLICANTS who hold
          </strong>
          240 ECTS or equivalent in
          <strong>
           the field of:
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Maritime Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Nautical and Maritime Transport
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Mechanical Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Civil Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Aerospace Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Electrical Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Electric Power Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Electronic Engineering
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Applied Mathematics
           </strong>
          </li>
          <li>
           <strong>
            Physics
           </strong>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          Applicants holding at least 240 ECTS in other technical disciplines can apply and their admission will be considered by Education Board.
         </p>
         <p>
          The SEAS 4.0 master’s course is offered to European and third country-students who fulfil the following additional requirements:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           at least B2 level of English-language proficiency according to the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) for Languages;
          </li>
          <li>
           6 IELTS with at least 5.0 point in each section;
          </li>
          <li>
           TOEFL (paper based) at least 550 points with 4.5 in the writing section; or
          </li>
          <li>
           TOEFL (IBT) 79 points with at least 17 points in every section.
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
         </p>
         <p>
          Other constraints are taken into account when allocating EMJMD scholarships:
         </p>
         <ul>
          <li>
           No more than three students from the same nationality can be selected in the main list
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </article>
      </main>

        <aside class="footer-widget widget widget_block widget_text" id="block-2">
         <p class="has-luminous-vivid-amber-color has-text-color">
          <strong>
           SEAS 4.0

   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   const lazyloadRunObserver = () => {
					const lazyloadBackgrounds = document.querySelectorAll( `.e-con.e-parent:not(.e-lazyloaded)` );
					const lazyloadBackgroundObserver = new IntersectionObserver( ( entries ) => {
						entries.forEach( ( entry ) => {
							if ( entry.isIntersecting ) {
								let lazyloadBackground = entry.target;
								if( lazyloadBackground ) {
									lazyloadBackground.classList.add( 'e-lazyloaded' );
								}
								lazyloadBackgroundObserver.unobserve( entry.target );
							}
						});
					}, { rootMargin: '200px 0px 200px 0px' } );
					lazyloadBackgrounds.forEach( ( lazyloadBackground ) => {
						lazyloadBackgroundObserver.observe( lazyloadBackground );
					} );
				};
				const events = [
					'DOMContentLoaded',
					'elementor/lazyload/observe',
				];
				events.forEach( ( event ) => {
					document.addEventListener( event, lazyloadRunObserver );
				} );
  </script>
